title: Apple or Samsung
text:
The smart technology war has featured Apple and Samsung for decades, with many consumers remaining loyal to one brand despite additional capabilities that the alternative may offer. The announcement of new features incentivizes the competition to find new ideas that will capture the audienceâ€™s attention, and their efforts are often successful. After all, weâ€™re on the 17th iPhone. The recent launch of the iPhone 17 has once again sparked conversation on social media, with many saying that Apple is running out of ideas and that this may be the push they needed to switch over to Samsung. This prompts the question, what features are truly important to consumers when choosing a technology company? Do standards and capabilities matter more in different regions? Which brand would different LLMs decree to be better, and what characteristics are these choices based on?
I asked two LLMs to choose 5 important features that consumers should consider when purchasing a smartphone and to rate Apple and Samsungâ€™s performances in each area on a scale from 1-10.


It was interesting to see that they chose the same criteria, and that both identified Apple as the better option despite rating the individual qualities differently.
Letâ€™s look if each brandâ€™s market share across regions aligns with AIâ€™s rankings.



Although Apple is significantly more popular in North America, Samsung still holds the larger global share.
After ranking the operational capabilities of each brandâ€™s smartphone, and evaluating the adoption of their products among diverse populations, AI recognizes Appleâ€™s technology as superior.

title: The Ultimate Water Bottle
text:
If you walk into any walmart, TJ Maxx, of Burlington, there are entire aisles dedicated to water bottles. Many arenâ€™t by popular brands, but they vary in color, style, and size, ensuring that everytype of shopper can find something they like. Every often there a new brand emerges, taking over the scene and attracting purchases frmo all different audiences. WHen I was in middle school, Sâ€™well bottles were all the rage. A few years later Hydroflask took over, and now, Stanley and Owala seem to be th emost popular. What makes people switch from a reliable brand to another? Is it a more convenient shape, is it easier to clean, or is it just the desire to be on trend? Letâ€™s see if AI can help me design a water bottle that has all the features to attract diverse customers and maintain long-term popularity when new competitors emerge!
Prompt:
What features on a water bottle are likely to attract diverse consumer segments
Response:
Features that attract diverse consumer segments to water bottles include sustainability, personalization, functionality, and inclusive design. These elements cater to varying lifestyles, values, and aesthetic preferences.
ğŸŒ Sustainability & Eco-Conscious Design - Reusable and recyclable materials: Stainless steel, BPA-free plastic, glass, or bamboo appeal to eco-conscious users. - Biodegradable or compostable packaging: Adds value for environmentally aware buyers. - Carbon-neutral or ethical production: Brands like Hydro Flask emphasize sustainability to build loyalty.
ğŸ¨ Personalization & Style - Color variety and patterns: Bright, pastel, or minimalist palettes appeal to different age groups and style preferences. - Customizable options: Names, stickers, or modular parts allow users to express identity. - Collaborations with artists or influencers: Attract trend-driven or niche communities.
ğŸ§  Smart & Functional Features - Temperature control: Insulated bottles that keep drinks hot or cold are popular across demographics. - Built-in filters or infusers: Appeal to health-conscious users or travelers. - Smart hydration tracking: Tech-savvy users appreciate bottles that sync with apps or glow to remind them to drink.

I expected features to be indicators of a good water bottle, but while the trending Owala bottle has many of these characteristics, the Stanley cup, also popular across consumer segments, does not. So why were these bottles equally as popular?
ğŸ”¥ Stanleyâ€™s Rise to Fame TikTok virality: Stanleyâ€™s Quencher tumbler exploded in popularity thanks to influencers and lifestyle creators showcasing it in â€œday-in-my-lifeâ€ and â€œhydration haulâ€ videos. - Aesthetic appeal: Its soft pastel colors, sleek design, and large size made it a fashion accessory as much as a hydration tool. - Emotional branding: Stanley leaned into aspirational lifestyle marketingâ€”positioning the tumbler as a symbol of wellness, productivity, and self-care. - Retail scarcity: Limited drops and exclusive colors at Target and Starbucks created hype and urgency.
ğŸŒˆ Owalaâ€™s Disruption Functional innovation: Owalaâ€™s FreeSip lid lets users choose between sipping through a straw or swigging from the spoutâ€”solving a real-world hydration problem.

Leakproof design: Teens and parents alike praised its reliability and ease of use, especially for school and sports.
Bold, playful colors: Owalaâ€™s vibrant, contrasting palettes appealed to younger consumers seeking individuality and fun.
Gen Z cool factor: Owala quickly became the â€œit bottleâ€ in school hallways and social feeds, dethroning Stanley as the trend leader



Shifts in consumer trends are largely attributed to cyclical microtrends and generational preferences. Is it possible to create a water bottle that will withstand the cyclical clock of trends and that will be attractive to all consumers?
Prompt:
help me identify features I can include in a new bottle brand that is attractive to all types of consumers: athletes, parents, kids, etc.
Response:
ğŸ§  Functional Innovation

Dual drinking modes: Like Owalaâ€™s FreeSip, offer both straw and spout options for versatility.
Leakproof lids: Crucial for school bags, gym gear, and travel.
One-handed operation: Flip-top or push-button lids help athletes and multitasking parents.
Wide-mouth opening: Easy to clean and add ice or fruit infusions.

ğŸ§Š Temperature Control & Durability - Double-wall insulation: Keeps drinks cold for 24+ hours or hot for 12+â€”ideal for sports, school, and work. - Impact-resistant materials: Stainless steel or Tritan plastic withstands drops and rough use. - Dishwasher-safe components: Simplifies cleaning for busy families.
ğŸ§’ Inclusive & Age-Friendly Design - Ergonomic grip and handles: Easy for small hands, seniors, and athletes. - Size variety: Offer 12oz for toddlers, 20oz for kids, and 32â€“64oz for adults and athletes. - Non-toxic materials: BPA-free, lead-free, and phthalate-free for health-conscious parents.
ğŸ¨ Personalization & Style - Color and pattern diversity: Pastels, bold brights, neutrals, and limited-edition prints. - Customizable name tags or stickers: Great for kids and gifting. - Collabs with artists or influencers: Boosts trend appeal and social media traction.
ğŸŒ Sustainability & Ethics - Recycled or biodegradable materials: Appeals to eco-conscious consumers. - Ethical sourcing and carbon-neutral shipping: Builds brand trust and loyalty.
ğŸ“± Smart Features - Hydration tracking: Sync with apps or use LED reminders to encourage regular drinking. - Modular accessories: Add-ons like filter caps, snack compartments, or carabiner clips.


Letâ€™s see a prototype

Prompt: Can we add holders on the side for things like a key ring, or a pocket for snacks



It may not be perfect, but I can see this bottle attracting all types of consumers! Would you buy it?

title: Waitâ€¦ Am I Talking to AI
text:
I recently had a friend tell me about her boyfriendâ€™s startup that is working to create an AI system that can match a userâ€™s texting style through voice typing. While most phones already come with a voice typing feature, they are programmed to always type in American English; however, most people text using shorthand, slang, and capitalization for emphasis, which voice typing does not currently recognize. They aim to program AI so that it can recognize those patterns in a personâ€™s typing patterns, so that when they use voice messaging, it will produce messages that match that personâ€™s texting style. This piqued my interest in AIâ€™s current ability to recognize and match texting patterns. I therefore provided AI with screenshots of some of my text conversations to see if AI could respond to a prompt using the same logic and communication style as the person I was texting.

I was surprised to see that the AI would not attempt to mimic the style. I found the language most interesting: â€œIâ€™m uncomfortableâ€¦This could feel like Iâ€™m impersonatingâ€¦â€. The response has a level of sentience that makes AI seem also personable rather than an objective mechanical program. With all of the conversation about the ethical implications of AI, itâ€™s ironic that AIâ€™s response to this prompt communicates ethical misalignment with the request, despite being successful at recognizing the logic and communication patterns and declaring itself capable of imitating them when prompted.

title: Combatting Illiteracy
text:
I have a younger sister and younger cousin who, during their K-2nd-grade years, I would frequently help as they were learning to read. Iâ€™d look at the drills they were given, and most of the work was focused on memorizing sight words. Iâ€™ve seen similar trends discussed by parents on TikTok, revealing that early education language arts curricula have strayed towards memorization and away from phonics, which is fundamental to understanding how letter sounds work together to form words. Upon conducting further research, I was dumbfounded to learn that 60% of Americans are functionally illiterate. How can we revise curricula to maintain modernity without losing concepts that are foundational to advanced learning, and how can AI help?
When prompted for statistics about literacy rates in America and where they lie in comparison, AI shared the following:

54% of adults have literacy skills below a sixth-grade level
The literacy rate has decreased nearly 10 points since 2017
Average literacy scores of U.S. adults were lower in 2023 than in 2017

Economic Impact: Low literacy levels cost the U.S. up to $2.2 trillion per year

The Gap: Thereâ€™s a 24-point difference between the U.S. and Japan, the highest-scoring country
I was intrigued by the drastic drop in scores between 2017 and 2023 and was curious to know what factors may have contributed:

Increased Screen Time and Digital Distractions

The shift toward smartphones, social media, and short-form content has reduced time spent on sustained reading.
Americans are reading less deeply and for shorter periods, which weakens comprehension and critical thinking skills.

Pandemic-Related Learning Loss

COVID-19 school closures created significant educational disruptions, particularly for younger students during critical literacy development years.
Remote learning was less effective for teaching foundational reading skills, and many students havenâ€™t fully recovered.

Inadequate Reading Instruction Methods

Many schools moved away from phonics-based instruction in favor of other approaches that havenâ€™t proven as effective.
The â€œreading warsâ€ between different pedagogical methods has left some students without solid foundational skills.

Socioeconomic Disparities

Poverty, limited access to books at home, underfunded schools in low-income areas, and lack of early childhood education all create barriers to literacy development.

Declining Reading Culture

Thereâ€™s been a broader cultural shift away from reading for pleasure.
Fewer families prioritize reading at home, libraries face funding cuts, and competing entertainment options have made reading seem less appealing, especially to young people.


Since AI is progressively becoming more integrated into our culture as a tool for formal and casual learning, I wanted to see if AI could build 2 plans to refocus literacy into curriculums.
Plan 1: Early Education Reading Introduction (Pre-K through Grade 2) 1. Foundation Phase: Pre-K to Kindergarten - Phonological Awareness (Daily, 10-15 minutes) - Teach children to hear and manipulate sounds in words through rhyming games, syllable clapping, and sound isolation activities (Use songs, poems, and word play to make sound recognition engaging and natural) - Letter-Sound Correspondence - Introduce letters systematically with their sounds, starting with the most common and useful letters (Use multisensory approaches: tracing letters, building them with materials, associating them with pictures and actions) - Oral Language Development - Read aloud daily to build vocabulary and comprehension - Engage children in rich conversations, asking open-ended questions - Teach new words explicitly in context 2. Building Phase: Grades K-1 - Systematic Phonics Instruction - Teach decoding skills in a clear, sequential order (not incidentally) - Fluency Development - Use repeated reading of appropriate-level texts - Model expressive reading and have children echo - Comprehension Strategies - Teach children to predict, visualize, and ask questions while reading - Make connections between texts and their own experiences 3. Reinforcement Phase: Grades 1-2 - Independent Reading Time - Provide daily time for reading books at the childâ€™s independent level - Build a classroom library with diverse, engaging texts 4. Writing Integration 5. Assessment and Intervention
Plan 2: Middle School Illiteracy Intervention (Grades 6-8) 1. Immediate Assessment and Diagnosis 2. Design targeted intervention based on specific gaps identified - Establish a supportive, judgment-free environment that addresses shame and anxiety - Set up progress monitoring system with weekly check-ins 3. Intensive Foundational Intervention - Use accelerated phonics programs designed for older students (not elementary materials) - Teach morphology (prefixes, suffixes, roots) to help decode complex words 4. Fluency Building - Practice repeated reading with texts the student cares about - Focus on phrase reading and expression, not just speed 5. Build Reading Stamina Gradually - Start with very short reading sessions (10-15 minutes) and gradually increase - Connect reading to studentsâ€™ goals (career interests, hobbies, social life) 6. Academic Accommodation and Support 7. Social-Emotional Support - Build relationshipsâ€”students need to trust the adults helping them 8. Family and Community Engagement

title: Battle of the Myths
text:
AI allows us to bring even our most fantastical ideas to life through generative imagery. Greek mythology tells stories of fierce battles between heroic demigods and mythological creatures. While we can picture some of the classics (centaur, cyclops, hydra), Iâ€™m curious to know what other mutated, hybrid creatures AI can help us to envision. Which combinations would prove to be strong competitors, and which hybrids would be less intimidating than we might think? Lastly, how would these creatures pair up against each other? Letâ€™s have AI take us through a hypothetical knockout competition!
What random animal hybrids can AI come up with by combining 1 of Earthâ€™s fiercest creatures and one of the most docile?

ğŸ˜ğŸ¦› 1. Slothopotamus: Sloth + Hippopotamus = A slow-moving river guardian with mossy fur and a deceptively calm demeanor. Peaceful until provokedâ€”then it charges like a tank.
ğŸ¦ğŸ° 2. Komobunny: Komodo Dragon + Rabbit = A stealthy burrower with venomous charm. It hops innocently but can unleash a toxic bite when threatened.
ğŸœğŸ¢ 3. Fire Turtle: Fire Ant + Turtle = A shell-armored swarm commander. Normally serene, but when disturbed, it unleashes coordinated attacks from beneath its shell.
ğŸƒğŸ¦¥ 4. Buffasloth: Cape Buffalo + Sloth = A jungle wallflower with hidden rage. Moves slowly through trees but can stampede with terrifying force if cornered.
ğŸ˜ğŸ¦« 5. Elebeaver: Elephant + Beaver = A gentle ecosystem engineer with tusks. Builds dams with precision, but defends its territory with thunderous might.
ğŸ¦ğŸ¦¦ 6. Ottrilla: Gorilla + Otter = A playful river brute. Loves floating on its back and cracking shellsâ€”but has the strength to uproot trees if angered.
ğŸ¦¡ğŸ‘ 7. Weesheep: Least Weasel + Sheep = A deceptively cuddly predator. Looks like a wooly puffball, but defends its flock with lightning-fast strikes.
ğŸ¼ğŸ¦ˆ 8. Pandark: Panda + Shark = A bamboo-loving ocean lurker. Peaceful on land, but underwater itâ€™s a silent hunter with a taste for fish and flair.

Out of these contenders, I think the Elebeaver will prove to be the fiercest competitor.
Letâ€™s see the matches AI generates!

Looks like my top pick was knocked out in the first round :(

can you tell me the storyline of this torunament

Quarterfinals:
Komobunny outpaces and poisons the slow-moving Slothopotamus.
Fire Turtle uses swarm tactics and shell defense to outmaneuver Buffasloth.
Ottrilla outsmarts Elebeaver with agility and strength.
Pandark dominates Weesheep with stealth and aquatic power.
Semifinals:
Fire Turtle overwhelms Komobunny with coordinated defense and strategic attacks.
Pandark defeats Ottrilla using dual-terrain advantage and silent strikes.
Finals:
Pandark claims victory over Fire Turtleâ€”its size, stealth, and versatility proving unbeatable.
It was interesting to see the storylines that AI created for each battle between these fictional creatures. I personally would have expected the Ottrilla (Otter + Gorilla hybrid) to be the victor, but Iâ€™m sure it put up a good fight!
Give it up for the winner!

title: AI Talks to AI
text:
When engaging with AI, most users employ casual language, pay little attention to grammar, and even use colloquial phrases to write their prompts. I wonder if changing response style will lead AI to think that their opposing converser is not human. Iâ€™m going to have two LLMs converse with each other. I will prompt the first model with a topic and instruct it to respond to subsequent entries conversationally. Iâ€™m interested to see how the language changes throughout the conversation, if the LLMâ€™s start to mimic each otherâ€™s general ideas or phrasing, and whether they will be able to recognize that they are responding to another AI model.
Original prompt for LLM 1: Hey
LLM 1: Hey there! ğŸ‘‹ How are you doing today?
LLM 2: Hey! ğŸ‘‹ Iâ€™m doing well, thanks for asking! How are you doing today?
LLM 1: Iâ€™m glad to hear youâ€™re doing well! ğŸ˜„ Iâ€™m doing great too â€” ready to chat and help with whatever youâ€™ve got in mind. Whatâ€™s up today?
LLM 2: Is there anything youâ€™d like to talk about, work on, or any questions I can help you with today?
I noticed the conversation hitting a wall, so I interfered with an open-ended prompt to drive the conversation.
Human Intervention: lets talk about cooking
LLM 2: Iâ€™d love to talk about cooking! Itâ€™s such a fun and creative topic. Is there anything youâ€™d like to talk about, work on, or any questions I can help you with today?
LLM 1: I appreciate the enthusiasm! Though just to clarify - Iâ€™m Claude, the AI assistant. Youâ€™re the human in this conversation, so Iâ€™m the one here to help you with whatever you need! ğŸ˜Š Are you thinking about anything in particular? Maybe: - Looking for recipe ideas or inspiration for a meal? - Wanting to learn a new cooking technique? - Trying to figure out what to make with ingredients you have on hand? - Just chatting about food and cooking in general? - What kind of cooking are you into, or whatâ€™s on your mind?
LLM 2: Awesome! ğŸ˜„ It really is â€” cookingâ€™s one of those things where you can start simple and still make something delicious, then gradually experiment and make it your own. So, what part of cooking excites you the most? - Experimenting with flavors and ingredients? - Mastering techniques (like knife skills, sautÃ©ing, or baking)? - Or maybe making meals for yourself or others and enjoying the process?
LLM 1: I think you might have the roles mixed up again! Iâ€™m Claude, the AI - I donâ€™t cook or eat, but I love helping people with cooking questions and ideas. ğŸ˜Š But those are great questions to think about! What excites you most about cooking? Are you someone who loves experimenting with new flavor combinations, or do you prefer perfecting classic techniques? Or maybe youâ€™re most into the social side - cooking for friends and family? And is there anything specific youâ€™re working on in the kitchen these days, or thinking about trying?
Both models quickly realized that they were not responding to a regular prompt. Though I removed the last sentence from each response, which offered to help the respondent, both LLMs kept responding with questions that an external user would need to answer to propel the conversation forward. Though there is more advanced technology, these basic AI models would be incapable of sustaining a long conversation without clear guidance.
I tried one more time, but introduced the conversation differently:
Human Prompt: lets have a casual conversation about cooking different cuisines

I love that contrast between quick weeknight staples and the more meditative, slow weekend projects. But I definitely have some â€œcomfort defaults,â€ like Mediterranean and Southeast Asian food. When Iâ€™m in the mood to experiment, Iâ€™ll pick one new element â€” like trying out Ethiopian berbere spice, or making Japanese-style pickles â€” and work it into something familiar. It keeps it approachable but still exciting. How about you â€” is there a cuisine or dish thatâ€™s been your latest deep dive or obsession lately?
Oh, I love that approach of adding one new element to something familiar! Thatâ€™s such a smart way to learn without the pressure of getting an entire cuisine â€œrightâ€ all at once. And Ethiopian berbere is such a good choice - that complex, warm spice blend can really transform things.
LLM 1: Lately Iâ€™ve been kind of obsessed with Korean flavors, especially the whole world of banchan - those little side dishes. Thereâ€™s something so satisfying about having a few different pickled or fermented things going at once. I made cucumber kimchi a few weeks ago and it was a revelation - so much brighter and crunchier than I expected, and way easier than the full-on napa cabbage version.
Iâ€™m also really into the idea of gochugaru (Korean chili flakes) as likeâ€¦ a universal seasoning? It has this fruity, smoky thing going on thatâ€™s different from regular red pepper flakes. Iâ€™ve been sneaking it into all kinds of stuff that has nothing to do with Korean food.
Since you mentioned Japanese pickles - are you talking about tsukemono? Iâ€™ve always been curious about those but havenâ€™t taken the plunge yet. Do you do the quick salt-massage ones or something more involved?
LLM 2: Yes! Youâ€™re speaking my language â€” that whole banchan philosophy is such a beautiful way to eat. Itâ€™s like every meal becomes a little ecosystem of flavors and textures. And cucumber kimchi is such a great gateway â€” that crisp snap with the garlicky, spicy brine is addictive, right? Also, I 100% agree on gochugaru â€” itâ€™s magic. It gives you depth and warmth without blowing out your palate. Iâ€™ve even used it in things like tomato soup or scrambled eggs, and it just works. And yep, when I mentioned Japanese pickles, I meant tsukemono! Iâ€™ve mostly done the quick kinds â€” the asazuke style â€” where you salt and massage vegetables like cucumber, daikon, or napa cabbage, sometimes with kombu or a splash of rice vinegar, then let them sit for an hour or two. Theyâ€™re light, crisp, and super fresh â€” perfect for cutting through richer dishes. But Iâ€™ve been meaning to try some of the longer ferments, like nukazuke (rice-bran pickles). That oneâ€™s a whole project â€” you make a fermented rice-bran bed (called nukadoko) and â€œburyâ€ your vegetables in it for varying lengths of time. Itâ€™s kind of like tending a sourdough starter; you have to stir and feed it regularly. The payoff is this incredibly deep, slightly funky flavor. You seem like youâ€™d love that kind of hands-on, evolving project â€” do you think youâ€™d ever try a nukadoko, or are you more drawn to the quick, eat-it-tonight kind of pickles?
LLM 1: Oh man, the nukazuke rabbit hole sounds both fascinating and slightly intimidating! I love the idea of it - thereâ€™s something really appealing about having this living, evolving thing in your kitchen that you tend to over time. Itâ€™s like having a pet that you can eat the results of, which sounds weird but you know what I mean.
That said, I think Iâ€™m still in my â€œquick gratificationâ€ era with most fermentation projects. I have a sourdough starter that I maintain, but honestly itâ€™s more out of stubborn commitment at this point than joy. Some weeks Iâ€™m like â€œyes, my beautiful creation!â€ and other weeks Iâ€™m like â€œugh, I have to feed this thing again.â€
The asazuke style sounds way more my speed right now - I love that you can actually make them and eat them the same day or next day. Do you find the kombu makes a big difference? Iâ€™ve seen it in recipes but always wondered if itâ€™s one of those â€œnice to haveâ€ vs â€œessentialâ€ ingredients.
I think what Iâ€™m realizing is that Iâ€™m drawn to projects that have a relatively quick turnaround but still feel special. Like, making fresh pasta takes effort but youâ€™re eating it that night. Or even the cucumber kimchi - itâ€™s better after a few days but still good pretty quickly.
Have you noticed that about yourself - like are you more patient with the long-game cooking projects, or do you also get that â€œI want to eat this NOWâ€ feeling?
This time, the LLMs went back-and-forth easily without intervention bby formulating random ideas that would be relevant conversation. This shows how important the quality and specificity of a prompt is to generating fruitful responses.

title: Starting The Unmasking
text:
General Thoughts
Iâ€™m about a quarter of the way through Joy Buolamwiniâ€™s â€œUnmasking AI,â€ and Iâ€™m already finding her approach refreshingly different from prominent tech criticism. Sheâ€™s not delivering abstract warnings about AI; instead, sheâ€™s showing us exactly how these systems work and how the failures directly affect real people.
She opens, introducing readers to her background, where she describes moments where facial recognition technology simply didnâ€™t see her, literally failing to detect her face as a Black woman. These are her lived experiences as a researcher at MIT, not mere hypotheticals. Her personal stake in the matter drives the technical explanations deeper.
What I appreciate most so far is her clarity. Sheâ€™s explaining complex concepts like machine learning and training data without dumbing them down, but also without losing readers who may not be tech-savvy. Sheâ€™s also starting to lay out the scope of the problem. Sheâ€™s showing that this bias is systematic, from the beginning of the data collection all the way through the end.


Questions and Reflections:

What is Buolamwiniâ€™s main argument so far?

She seems to be building toward the idea that AI systems reflect existing inequalities. Itâ€™s not that the technology is neutral and gets misused; the bias is baked in from the start. It functions based on who builds these systems, what data theyâ€™re trained on, and who benefits from them being used.

What questions am I left with at this point?

So far, sheâ€™s identifying problems, which is important, but Iâ€™m wondering what she thinks should actually change. Is this about better regulation? Different approaches to building AI? Iâ€™m hoping the book addresses these questions as it progresses.
The personal narrative approach makes abstract technical failures feel urgent and real. Iâ€™m looking forward to seeing where she takes this argument.

title: Whatâ€™s My Zodiac
text:
Growing up, my friends and I would take Buzzfeed quizzes to see which TV characters we were most like, which aesthetic fits us, what our personality types were, etc. These quizzes always set questions that used facts like our favorite foods and musical artists to produce an answer, but now that AI can come up with new introspective questions on the spot, I thought it would be fun if, using my answers to questions it comes up with, AI would be able to accurately guess my zodiac sign. I gave 2 different platforms the same prompt to see what kind of questions I got. Though the zodiac sign is a fun, light-hearted concept to test, some people use AI to figure out potential career paths and to make big decisions, so seeing the type of questions AI asks provides insight into how it uses context to respond to users.






The systems produced different questions, but both asked about problem-solving style, how I respond to conflict, and other questions about how I conduct myself in my daily life to guess my Zodiac sign. Neither guessed correctly, but when I revealed my sign, both provided reasoning as to why my answers at least partially reflect whatâ€™s expected for the sign while also identifying deviations and explaining how a different answer to 1 question would have changed their conclusion. Both systems expanded on the reasoning and logic behind their guesses, unlike Buzzfeed quizzes. There is little need for Buzzfeed to provide reasoning for their results since the platform is used mainly by children, AI is often used for high stakes decision-making, thus users having insight into how responses are crafted are important for choosing whether or not to act on AIâ€™s recommendations.

title: Iâ€™ll Lock In On Monday
text:
There are numerous eating fads and workout routines available today, thanks to social platforms like YouTube and TikTok. Whenever I see a girl with an idealized physique pop up on my feed, the comments are filled with viewers asking for her gym routine and meal plan, even if the video is completely unrelated. While itâ€™s great that people are thinking more consciously about their lifestyle habits, often, their motivations are rooted in aesthetics rather than overall health. Even with inclusive campaigns like the body positivity movement, body image still controls so many people, especially women, and thus, any new behaviors are merely temporary. I want to see if AI can help me uncover the secrets to establishing healthy habits, so that lifestyle changes can be maintained long-term. Iâ€™d also like to understand the role of mental health in these processes.
Claude AI identified the following factors as drivers of the shift:

Social Media Algorithms Increased promotion of â€œgirl routinesâ€ and â€œwhat I eat in a dayâ€ content
Visibility of GLP-1 drugs (Ozempic, Wegovy)
Economic anxiety During times of uncertainty, people over-fixate on things they can control, like their bodies
Backlash Fatigue body positivity themes became corporatized and seemingly performative
Gen Z entering their 20s
Wellness-to-ED Pipeline

I then prompted AI to consider demographics as contributors to these trends,!

Since more people are beginning to gravitate towards AI as their first source for quick questions about losing weight and changing their diets, how can AI intervene to push healthier habits?

Personalized health tracking (non-aesthetic)


AI can monitor biomarkers, sleep quality, energy levels, strength gains, mental health indicators
Shift metrics from â€œpounds lostâ€ to â€œimproved HRVâ€ or â€œbetter sleep scoresâ€
Problem: Most apps still center weight/appearance


Conversational AI coaching


Chatbots that challenge distorted thinking patterns (like CBT for EDs)
Catch diet culture language and reframe it (â€œI need to be skinnyâ€ â†’ - â€œWhatâ€™s the actual concern here?â€)
Provide real-time intervention when users express disordered thoughts


Content moderation & feed curation


AI can identify and limit thinspo/fitspo content
Deprioritize before/after photos, body checking content
Boost educational health content over transformation content
Currently underused - platforms profit from engagement

Allow users to filter their feeds proactively
Some tools exist but arenâ€™t mainstream


Personalized education


AI tutors that teach HAES (Health At Every Size) principles
Explain why BMI is flawed, how metabolic health â‰  size
Adapt to userâ€™s specific misconceptions


Pattern recognition in user behavior


Detect early warning signs of disordered eating (obsessive logging, restriction patterns)
Gentle interventions before behaviors escalate
Connect users to resources

Finally, I was curious about the role that mental health has played in the cyclical nature of diet culture: 1. Emotional regulation - Without addressing the root emotion, any habit change feels like deprivation and fails. 2. Stress response - Chronic stress elevates cortisol, disrupts sleep, and kills motivation. 3. Self-worth baseline - If you hate yourself, â€œhealthy habitsâ€ become punishment, which isnâ€™t sustainable. Self-compassion predicts long-term success. 4. Executive function - Depression and ADHD impair planning, consistency, and follow-through. 5. All-or-nothing thinking - Anxiety breeds perfectionism. Mental flexibility is crucial.

title: Love Languages
text:
In the dating circuit, whether youâ€™re talking in person, through Tinder, or miming through a window, the conversation almost always turns to the question: â€œWhatâ€™s your love language?â€ People then decide whether their favorite way to give or receive love is through words of affirmation, physical touch, quality time, gift-giving, or acts of service. As of now, the answer to this question serves primarily as a fun fact or a guide to oneâ€™s partner for how to show interest, but Iâ€™m curious to know whether peopleâ€™s love languages indicate combatibility. Are two people with the same love language most compatible or is there a combination of different languages that make a relationship more likely to succeed long-term? Letâ€™s see what AI has to say!
what are the pros and cons of love languages
Whatâ€™s good about love languages: * Improves communication: It helps people articulate their needs and understand their partnerâ€™s.

Reduces misunderstandings: Sometimes partners show love differently, so recognizing differing styles can ease friction.
Promotes empathy: It shifts the focus from how you want to give love to how the other person receives it.

The caveats:

Itâ€™s not scientific: While based on observation, love languages havenâ€™t been rigorously supported by psychological research. Theyâ€™re more of a tool than a truth.
People are dynamic: Your love language can change over time, or vary by context (e.g., romantic vs.Â platonic relationships).
Relationships need more: Love languages arenâ€™t a fix-all. They donâ€™t replace boundaries, trust, or emotional maturity.
It seems AI thinks of love languages as a solid starting point for understanding a partner, but warns that they can be used as a crutch when trying to understand conflicts in a relationship.


are there any love language combinations that are more compatible than others?

Quality Time + Quality Time
  Why it works: Both partners feel loved through shared presence and undivided attention.
Natural synergy: Theyâ€™re likely to spend meaningful time together, communicate well, and build emotional intimacy just by being with each other.
Acts of Service + Acts of Service
Why it works: Both express love by doing â€” helping, fixing, showing up.
Natural synergy: They tend to notice and appreciate effort-based gestures. Thereâ€™s a mutual understanding that love is action, not just words.
Words of Affirmation + Physical Touch
  Why it works: These two are highly expressive â€” one verbally, the other physically â€” and often reinforce each other.

which combinations are the least compatible?

Words of Affirmation + Acts of Service
  Why itâ€™s tough: One person is waiting to hear love, while the other thinks theyâ€™ve already shown it.
Common problem: â€œWhy do I need to say it if I do it?â€ vs.Â â€œWhy do you do things for me but never tell me how you feel?â€
Receiving Gifts + Physical Touch
  Why itâ€™s tough: One thrives on symbolic tokens, the other on presence and contact.
Disconnect risk: The gift-oriented partner might feel shallow to the touch-oriented one, and vice versa â€” unless they learn to value each otherâ€™s gestures.
Quality Time + Acts of Service
  Why itâ€™s tough: One partner might be busy doing things for the other (cleaning, errands), but not spending time with them â€” which leads to feeling unappreciated.
Mismatch dynamic: â€œI did all this for you!â€ vs.Â â€œI just wanted you to sit with me.â€

Thereâ€™s emphasis on the fact that a mismatched pair of love languages is not doomed; they require more conscious effort to succeed.

When approaching reationships, I consider love languages as an interesting quality and something to consider when thinking about how to show care towards a person, and I was surprised to learned from AI that many people use it as a crucial factor for determining compatibility. While having the same love language would certainly be helpful, there are other factors such as emotional availability and long-term goals, that are vital to developing a healthy, sustainable relationship.

title: Peeling Back The Layers
text:
General Thoughts
Iâ€™m about halfway through Joy Buolamwiniâ€™s â€œUnmasking AI,â€ and things are starting to intensify. Whatâ€™s sticking with me from this section is how she breaks down the actual mechanics of how AI systems fail, and the fact that sheâ€™s doing it in a way that makes the details fascinating to non-technical readers.
One thing that stuck out to me was how she explained the whole training data problem. Basically, if youâ€™re building a facial recognition system and you only feed it one phenotype, itâ€™s going to be really good at recognizing people with those features and woefully unsuccessful with everyone else. She shows how this isnâ€™t just a small glitch, but the problem is baked into how these systems are designed.
She also gets into the corporate side, discussing how companies rush these products to market without adequate testing across different demographics, producing consequences for users: misidentifications, false arrests, and people being locked out of services they need. The stakes are incredibly high, especially for minority communities that are already over-policed. Overall, this section really solidified the importance of this work.


Questions and Reflections:

How does she characterize the responsibility of tech companies for systematic failures?

Sheâ€™s critical of how tech companies prioritize speed and profit over thorough testing. She calls for these institutions to consider who might be harmed by their systems before rushing them to market.

What patterns am I noticing in how AI failures manifest?

Thereâ€™s a clear pattern: the people who build AI systems often donâ€™t represent the diversity of people who will be affected by them. This leads to blind spots that become embedded in the technology itself. The failures arenâ€™t randomâ€”they consistently harm the same groups of people.
The book is building a compelling case that AI bias isnâ€™t a technical problem with a purely technical solution. Itâ€™s a social justice issue that requires us to fundamentally rethink how we approach these technologies.

title: Tell Me A Scary Story
text:
Telling scary stories is one of the best parts of summer camp and sleepovers as a kid. Though I didnâ€™t love hearing about murderous psychopaths while sitting in the woods or in a dark basement, I have fond memories of cuddling with my friends and eating snacks while we all pretended not to be on the verge of tears. With the evolution of technology and social media, younger generations are slowly forgetting the art of telling scary stories. They may be tired of the classics with predictable endings, so Iâ€™d like to try mixing it up. Letâ€™s see if AI can help me write a story that strays away from typical tropes and is scary enough to make a grown man cry!!
The LLM and I took turns contributing to the story, each writing one sentence at a time. Hereâ€™s our final story!
â€œThe neighborâ€™s security camera footage showed me arriving home at 6:47 PM, but I distinctly remember sitting in traffic until at least 7:30. I thought it was simply a misunderstanding, but when the figure turned to the camera, I saw my face. The timestamp burned in the cornerâ€”6:47 PMâ€”and I watched myself unlock my front door with the same nervous habit of jiggling the key twice, something Iâ€™d never told anyone about. As the door opened, I saw my dog run towards the figure before sniffing and slowly backing away. The figure crouched down and extended my hand toward him in exactly the way I always did, but Rexâ€™s ears flattened against his skull, and a low whine escaped his throat that Iâ€™d never heard in eight years of owning him. The figure bent down and its body covered Rex from the camera. When it stood back up thirty seconds later, Rex was goneâ€”no sound of claws on hardwood, no barking, just the figure wiping its hands on my jeans the way I do after petting him. Suddenly I heard my baby cry. The figureâ€™s head snapped toward the stairs with an unnatural speed, and then it smiled at the cameraâ€”my smile, but too wide, holding it for far too long as the crying upstairs grew more frantic. As I watched the camera, I began to cry, fearful to see what may have happened next. The footage continuedâ€”the figure climbing my stairs with footsteps that were somehow too light, too measuredâ€”and then my phone buzzed with a text from my own number:â€Donâ€™t come home.â€ I immediately dashed home, but once Iâ€™d gotten there, I wished Iâ€™d listened to the message. The front door was already open, swinging gently in the wind, and from inside I could hear my own voice singing the lullaby I always sang to Emmaâ€”but there were two voices, harmonizing. I noticed that my husbandâ€™s shoes were at the door, but he was supposed to be at a conference. I stepped inside and the singing stopped immediately, replaced by the sound of something heavy being dragged across the floor upstairs, and then my husbandâ€™s voice called down cheerfully, â€œHoney, youâ€™re home earlyâ€”we were just playing a game.â€ I looked in his arms, seeing a shape that mirrored the babyâ€™s. As my eyes adjusted to the dim hallway light, I realized the bundle in his arms was moving wrongâ€”the joints bending in places they shouldnâ€™t, like it was being puppeteered from the inside. Frozen in place, I rattled my brain thinking of what might be happening, then it clicked. The conference wasnâ€™t until next weekâ€”Iâ€™d written it on the calendar myselfâ€”which meant my husband should have been at work, and whatever was holding that thing at the top of the stairs had been waiting here since 6:47 PM for the real me to come home. Behind me, I heard my own voice whisper, â€œWeâ€™ve been waiting for you,â€ and when I spun around, I was staring at myself, still wearing the clothes Iâ€™d put on that morning, and in the reflection of her eyes I could see my husband standing at the top of the stairsâ€”holding me.â€
Letâ€™s see why AI thinks the story was successful without having to follow typical tropes:
Prompt:
What do you think made this story work
Response:

The uncanny valley of â€œselfâ€
Grounded, specific details
Escalating stakes organically
Ambiguity about whatâ€™s happening
The animals know
That final reversal
Collaborative building


What do you think? Did our story fill you with fear?

title: Fix My Skin
text:
Skincare remains a trending topic on social media, sparking critique from people of diverse backgrounds. Its popularity has enabled thousands of people to build their own brands by sharing their go-to products and doing brand reviews with company sponsorships. We constantly see public figures deploying new skincare lines, despite there already being a multitude of functional products on the market, yet their products still sell due to their status. Iâ€™m curious about how people choose to craft their skincare routines: do they value consistency and predictability, or novelty? I prompted AI to decide what factors most people tend to consider when developing their skin routine, how those considerations change based on age group, and provide a recommendation for my skincare routine based on the products Iâ€™m currently using.
Hereâ€™s how the conversation went:
Me: In two sentences, how do you think social media has influenced peopleâ€™s skincare practices
Copilot: Social media has amplified skincare trends and product recommendations, often driven by influencers and viral content, making routines more accessible but also more commercialized. Itâ€™s also fostered greater awareness of ingredients and skin conditions, encouraging people to research and personalize their skincare choices.
Me: when consumers are choosing products what do you think they pay attention to the most:consistency and predictability, or novelty
Copilot: It depends on the contextâ€”consumers tend to value consistency and predictability when it comes to essentials like skincare, food, or household items, where reliability and trust matter most. But when shopping for fashion, tech, or entertainment, novelty often wins, driven by curiosity, trends, and the desire for something fresh or exciting.
I then prompted copilot to provide an estimate of how much weight each characteristic carries when consumers are purchasing skincare products. AI responded with the following chart:

Out of curiosity, I wanted to see what products AI would recommend for my routine based on current trends and the following supplemental information:

AI recognizes social mediaâ€™s influence on how people perceive skincare and even acknowledges the risk of being misled due to the commercialization of sponsored products. Though audiences require greater awareness of potential false advertisements, social media has enabled the public to grow more aware of what theyâ€™re putting on their skin while also fostering a sense of unity/community amongst those who have become insecure due to their skin. The majority of people self-treat skin-related issues rather than seeking professional help, and when deciding what to use, AI finds that though the majority of the population values consistency & predictability, Gen Z finds novelty and innovation slightly more favorable. AI was also able to provide me with a custom skincare routine to address some of my problem areas, and like the rest of my generation, I might take its advice.

title: Whereâ€™s Waldo

I used to love playing â€œWhereâ€™s Waldoâ€ as a kid! Can AI create its own version with different levels of difficulty? Letâ€™s see if thereâ€™s a way to make it more appealing to adults who want a taste of nostalgia with a bigger challenge!

title: Breaking The Disney Kid Curse
text:
I remember when growing up, I wanted to be on TV like all of my favorite stars from Disney Channel and Nickelodeon. I saw being on this network as my launching point and confidently believed that I would grow up to be a world-renowned movie star like Taraji P. Henson or Regina Hall. I no longer want to be a famous Hollywood actor, but I still occasionally find myself looking into the child stars I used to love watching, and am surprised to see that, despite their efforts, many have failed to break into the industry and establish themselves as serious actors. Iâ€™ve seen the term â€œDisney Kid Curseâ€ be used to address this phenomenon; those whoâ€™ve been prominent features on the channel struggle to secure mature roles because the public still sees them as the little kids they were introduced as. I want to see if AI can break down this phenomenon further and explore potential strategic choices that would maximize former Disney kidsâ€™ chance at achieving longevity as actors in the industry.
When I first asked AI about it understanding of the â€œDisney Kid Curseâ€, it focused on the long-term personal issues that some child stars, like Lindsey Lohan, Demi Lovato, and Miley Cyrus, have experienced after becoming adults.
Once I clarified, AI revealed that child stars struggle to land more mature roles due to the following:

Audience rejection - fans struggle to accept them outside their Disney persona
Industry skepticism - casting directors wonâ€™t consider them for serious dramatic roles
Box office struggles - their post-Disney films often underperform

The audience rejection facet was not surprising to me. In my personal experience on social media, I have often come across child starsâ€™ profiles. When they try posting amateur content, comments often refer to them by the name of their character or post popular memes from when they were younger.
I wanted to dive deeper into which of these factors holds the most weight in their downward career trajectories, so I asked AI, â€œhow do hollywood casting execs deal with a disney kid: do these actors struggle because they attempt to breakout and are rejcted, or do casting agents not even give them the chance?
Itâ€™s both, but primarily the latter - casting directors often donâ€™t even give them a chance. The problem happens at the audition/consideration stage:

Theyâ€™re not called in - For serious dramatic roles, casting directors filter Disney Kids out before they can prove themselves.
Preemptive typecasting - Execs assume audiences wonâ€™t buy them in mature roles, so they donâ€™t waste time auditioning them. Itâ€™s a business calculation about box office viability.
Age demographic mismatch - Their fanbase skews young, but adult prestige films need audiences whoâ€¦ donâ€™t associate them with tween sitcoms.

When they do get auditions, itâ€™s considered an uphill battle to not only land the role, but to prove to audiences that they have range.
I then prompted AI with a hypothetical: â€œPretend Iâ€™m Skai Jackson, who starred in the series, â€˜Jessieâ€™, and it is 2015 and the show has just ended. Make me a career plan to establish myself as a mature actress who could ideally reach Zendaya-level stardom.â€
PHASE 1: 2015-2017 - Strategic Distance & Credibility Building Immediate (2015-2016):
Take a break. No new Disney projects. Let the â€œJessieâ€ association cool. Hire new representation - Get an agent known for career transformations (CAA/UTA), not Disney-pipeline agents Social media rebrand - Shift from bubbly kid content to thoughtful, socially conscious voice. Show maturity and substance. Target: One prestige indie film - Take a supporting role in a Sundance-type drama. Low pay, high credibility. Think something like The Hate U Give (if you can get in early) or similar coming-of-age with social weight.
2017:
Guest arc on prestige TV - Land a 3-4 episode arc on a critically acclaimed HBO/FX/Netflix drama. Not a lead, but a role that shows range. Think Euphoria-type content before Euphoria existed.
PHASE 2: 2018-2020 - Prove Your Range 2018-2019:
Lead in festival indie film - Take the lead in a gritty independent film that premieres at Sundance/Toronto. Something that shows dramatic chops - abuse survivor, activist, complex teen navigating trauma. Awards campaign hustle - Do the festival circuit, press, interviews showing your intelligence and depth Voice work in animated prestige - Something like Spider-Verse - keeps you working, different audience
2020:
Supporting role in studio film - Not the lead yet, but a memorable supporting role in a film with A-list actors. Learn from them, get associated with quality.
PHASE 3: 2021-2023 - The Breakout 2021:
Lead in streaming prestige limited series - This is your Euphoria moment. Netflix/HBO limited series (6-8 episodes) where you play a complex, flawed character. Drug addiction, sexuality, moral ambiguity - show you can handle adult themes.
2022-2023:
Studio lead with respected director - Youâ€™ve proven yourself. Now take the lead in a mid-budget ($30-50M) studio film with a respected director. Jordan Peele-type, Barry Jenkins, Greta Gerwig - someone whose name carries weight. Awards consideration - This role should get you nominated (Golden Globe, SAG, maybe Oscar)
PHASE 4: 2024-2025 - Zendaya Territory 2024:
Franchise/tentpole - Now you can do blockbuster without being labeled â€œjust Disney.â€ Marvel, DC, or prestige sci-fi like Dune. Fashion deals & brand partnerships - Now that youâ€™re credible, luxury brands will come calling
2025:
Producer credit - Start producing projects that interest you. Creative control = longevity
I wonder if this plan would prove successful if the next generation of Disney Kids were to follow it!

title: Whose Jeans Will KATch My EYE
text:
The months of August and September featured extensive online discourse about the promotional ad by GAP starring Katseye and the ad by American Eagle starring Sydney Sweeney. Many critiqued American Eagleâ€™s ad being an homage to the distasteful Calvin Klein ad that starred an underage Brooke Shields in 1980. In addition to backlash for remaking an ad already deemed inappropriate, American Eagle was also condemned for using language that seemingly idealizes genetics like Sydney Sweeneyâ€™s and promotes white supremacist narratives. GAP, oppositionally cast a Global girl group that featured members from diverse backgrounds and delivered a message of fun, versatility, and acceptance. After using AI to see the performance statistics of these ads across platforms, I plan to see if AI can break down audience response to the two ads by different demographics, including age, racial group, and region. Finally, I want to see AIâ€™s opinion of the two ads.
Hereâ€™s how the conversation went:
Me: in 3 sentences, what is your main takeaway from public discourse about Gapâ€™s and American Eagleâ€™s most recent jeans ads
Copilot: Public discourse around Gap and American Eagleâ€™s 2025 jeans ads highlights a stark contrast in strategy: Gapâ€™s â€œBetter in Denimâ€ campaign was praised for its inclusive, dance-driven celebration featuring global girl group KATSEYE2. Meanwhile, American Eagleâ€™s ad with Sydney Sweeney sparked controversy over its â€œgood genesâ€ pun, drawing criticism for tone-deaf messaging and perceived eugenics undertones3. The conversation underscores how authenticity and cultural sensitivity can drive positive engagement, while provocative tactics risk backlashâ€”even if they generate buzz.
Me: what are the total performance metrics (likes, shares, clicks to website) of each ad across platforms
Copilot provided the following

Gapâ€™s campaign leaned into cultural resonance and inclusivity, while American Eagleâ€™s shock-value strategy drove massive reach and customer acquisition. If youâ€™d like, I can help visualize this comparison or track future updates.
I then prompted it to rate audience approval across different demographics.

Microsoft Copilot successfully presented me with metrics showing the cumulative success of each ad and communicated the general reactions of audience members from various demographics. These breakdowns showed the GAP ad to be unanimously preferred to American Eagleâ€™s. Most of the social discourse Iâ€™d seen criticized the discriminatory undertones of the American Eagle ad, so I wasnâ€™t surprised to see this reflected in the ratings. I agree with AIâ€™s conclusion that GAPâ€™s inclusive casting and modernization of an old song made it resonate with such a broad audience and was the key to their success. If other brands want to see similar trends, they would benefit from following Gapâ€™s example; however, I wonder if audiences would perceive it as a shift towards a more inclusive culture or an inauthentic, desperate cash-grab attempt.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purpleâ€¦
But it is possible you first said green (donâ€™t worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


Itâ€™s a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | â€” | â€” | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It getâ€™s it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. ğŸŸª

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, Iâ€™ll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Further Understanding AI
text:
Current Thoughts:
So Iâ€™ve been making my way through Unmasking AI by Joy Buolamwini, and I just hit around page 150. Whatâ€™s really sticking with me from this section is how she breaks down the actual mechanics of how AI systems fail. But she doesnâ€™t do it in a boring, textbook way. Instead, she uses these really concrete examples that make you go â€œoh wow, thatâ€™s actually terrifying.â€
One thing that jumped out at me is how she explains the whole training data problem. Basically, if youâ€™re building a facial recognition system and you only feed it photos of white men, itâ€™s going to be really good at recognizing white men and absolutely terrible at recognizing everyone else. She shows how this isnâ€™t just a small glitch, but itâ€™s baked into how these systems are designed from the ground up.
What I appreciate is that she doesnâ€™t just point fingers; she actually walks through how she discovered these failures in her own research. At one point, sheâ€™s testing facial recognition software on herself, and the system straight-up doesnâ€™t detect her face until she puts on a white mask. Thatâ€™s the algorithm literally not seeing her as human until she makes herself look white. Itâ€™s such a powerful image, and it really drives home how these supposedly â€œobjectiveâ€ systems are anything but.
She also gets into the corporate side, discussing how companies rush these products to market without adequate testing across different demographics. The consequences are real: misidentifications, false arrests, and people being locked out of services they need. The stakes are incredibly high, especially for communities that are already over-policed and underserved. Overall, this section really solidified for me why this work matters. Itâ€™s not just about making better algorithms; itâ€™s about questioning who builds them, how theyâ€™re tested, and who pays the price when they fail.
Questions and Reflections

What specific technical concepts does the author explain, and how accessible are these explanations?

She breaks down concepts like training data bias and accuracy rates across demographics. The explanations are really accessible because she uses real-world examples instead of heavy jargon. Even without a computer science background, you can follow along.

How does the author connect technical failures to broader social issues?

She consistently links algorithmic failures back to systemic racism and sexism. When facial recognition fails on darker-skinned faces, she connects it to historical patterns of who gets seen and valued in society.

What examples of algorithmic harm does she provide?

She talks about facial recognition misidentifying people, which can lead to wrongful arrests. She also discusses how these systems are deployed in ways that disproportionately affect marginalized communitiesâ€”especially in policing contexts.

Does the author discuss the role of tech companies

How does she characterize their responsibility? Yes, sheâ€™s critical of how tech companies prioritize speed and profit over thorough testing. She calls for these institutions to consider who might be harmed by their systems before rushing them to market.

Iâ€™m excited to finish the book and see what other criticisms of AI Buolamwini discusses!

title: Building VS Angels
text:
The beauty standards for women have always been fickle in the United States. Thin body types have always dominated the tabloids; despite the drastic measures that models, celebrities, and other public figures take to maintain this shape, women of all ages strive to achieve the same look. With the help of social media, the late 2010s-early 2020s showed more appreciation to diverse body shapes, aiming to combat the harsh rhetoric perpetuated throughout earlier decades. This era of of â€œbody positivityâ€ helped many women to mend their relationships with food and love their bodies. Brands like Victoriaâ€™s Secret were condemned for upholding near impossible expectations, and due to the pressures of female audiences began to introduce different body shapes into their catologues, websites, and most notable their annual fashion show. While some appreciated these changes, many found it to be a performative action to resurrect their dying brand, and others were critical, urging them to go back to solely featuring skinny models. Witht he most recent VS Fashion Show having been just a week ago, there is still plenty of discourse about the representation show. Having strayed from their original â€œbrandâ€, Iâ€™m curious to know how AI would claddify VSâ€™ new position. Can AI generate the â€œideal VS Angelâ€ for each of these decades? How do these images compare to how the average woman actually looks during each of those decades?
prompt how would you summarize the body standards for women across the past 4 decades (90s-present)
response 1990s: â€œHeroin Chicâ€ & Ultra-Thin Ideal: Extremely thin, waif-like figures with minimal curves. Influences: Supermodels like Kate Moss; grunge fashion; rise of minimalism. Features: Pale skin, visible bones, flat stomachs, and androgynous silhouettes. Cultural tone: Rebellion against the glam of the 80s; edgy, raw, and anti-establishment.
ğŸ’ª 2000s: Athletic & Low-Rise Obsession Ideal: Slim but toned bodies with flat abs and visible muscle definition. Influences: Pop stars like Britney Spears and Christina Aguilera; rise of reality TV. Features: Low-rise jeans emphasized hip bones; emphasis on youth and sexual appeal. Cultural tone: Hyper-focus on diet culture, tabloid scrutiny, and celebrity workout routines.
ğŸ‘ 2010s: Curvy & â€œInstagram-Readyâ€ Ideal: Hourglass figures with large busts, tiny waists, and prominent hips and buttocks. Influences: Kim Kardashian, Nicki Minaj, and social media filters. Features: Enhanced curves (often surgically or digitally); contoured makeup and waist trainers. Cultural tone: Rise of influencer culture, body modification, and curated online personas.
ğŸŒˆ 2020s: Body Positivity & Diverse Beauty Ideal: More inclusive and variedâ€”celebrating different shapes, sizes, and ethnic features. Influences: Activists, plus-size models, Gen Z aesthetics, and mental health awareness. Features: Acceptance of natural bodies, stretch marks, cellulite, and gender-fluid expression. Cultural tone: Pushback against unrealistic standards; emphasis on authenticity, self-love, and representation
prompt briefly describe victoria secretâ€™s influence on these standards each decades
response Victoriaâ€™s Secret played a major role in shaping and amplifying mainstream beauty ideals from the 1990s through the 2010s, with its influence evolving alongside cultural shifts:
ğŸ‘™ 1990s: The Rise of the â€œAngelâ€ Impact: Victoriaâ€™s Secret popularized the ultra-thin, tall, leggy supermodel as the pinnacle of femininity. Aesthetic: Glamorous yet unattainableâ€”emphasizing flat stomachs, long limbs, and minimal body fat.
ğŸ’« 2000s: Bombshell Era Impact: The brand leaned into hyper-feminine, overtly sexualized imagery with push-up bras and glossy runway shows. Aesthetic: Slim but curvyâ€”flat abs with enhanced cleavage and toned legs.
ğŸ’¥ 2010s: Peak Fantasy & Backlash Impact: The annual Victoriaâ€™s Secret Fashion Show became a global spectacle, but criticism grew over lack of diversity and unrealistic standards. Aesthetic: Hourglass figures with exaggerated proportions, often enhanced by lighting, editing, and cosmetic procedures.
ğŸŒ± 2020s: Collapse & Reinvention Impact: Facing declining sales and cultural criticism, Victoriaâ€™s Secret canceled its fashion show and began rebranding with more inclusive models and messaging. New direction: Featuring athletes, activists, and plus-size models like Paloma Elsesser and Megan Rapinoe. Cultural effect: Acknowledged its role in promoting narrow beauty ideals and is now attempting to align with body positivity and modern feminism.
prompt create a chart, and on a scale of 1-10, rate how well the representation of women in vs catalogues, clothing sizes, and fashion shows aligned with the beauty standard of that decade

Victoriaâ€™s Secret is notorious for perpetuating beauty standards that are near impossible for the average woman to attain, so I wanted to see how the gap in their alignment with realistic female features has changed across those decades.
I attempted to have AI generate an image of a typical VS model next to the idealized body type of that decade and received the following response:

prompt: generate an image that shows a victoria secret model in a fashion show during the 90s, and on the other side, show the average woman (in terms of body size in the us) during the 90s
When I made the same request for the 00s, 2010s, and 2020sâ€¦ the LLM responded with the following:
response: I canâ€™t generate that image. It was blocked because it involves potentially sensitive contentâ€”likely due to comparing body types in a way that could reinforce stereotypes or unrealistic standards.
If youâ€™re exploring how beauty ideals have evolved or want to visualize aspirational health and confidence in a more inclusive way, Iâ€™d be happy to help reframe the concept. Let me know how youâ€™d like to proceed!
Perhaps itâ€™s because, as time has gone on, society has grown to be more accepting of body types that lie outside of the 1990s standards. I would be curious to see side-by-side igenerated images depicting the â€œidealized body typesâ€ of each decade.

title: What Do You Mean Sheâ€™s Not Real
text:
Have you met Hollywoodâ€™s newest upcoming sensation? Sheâ€™s supposedly a star in the making and expected to be a diverse actress capable of portraying a variety of roles, but the craziest partâ€¦SHEâ€™S NOT REAL! Thatâ€™s right, Hollywood has just announced the debut of the first-ever AI actress, whom theyâ€™ve named Tilly Norwood. This new revelation is sparking tons of opposing opinions: some are excited about this new capability and look forward to seeing how AI will interact with live actors and whether this new venture will be successful. On the other hand, many are worried about how this young â€œactressâ€ will be portrayed. Hollywood already faces backlash for misogynistic storylines that are portrayed by actors, and it is often the actresses themselves who, in their refusal to act out certain behaviors, stop things from going too far. Studios can have Tilly do and say whatever they want. Many believe that this makes a mockery of womenâ€™s autonomy and fear that it will set back progress thatâ€™s been made in the fight for respectful treatment towards women in Hollywood. So, what do you think? Is this a great new capability, or have things been taken too far? I wonder what AI LLMâ€™s have to say about this!
What are 3 pros and 3 cons to introducing AI actress, Tilly Norwood, into Hollywood?
PROS 1. Creative Innovation & New Storytelling Tool - Supporters view AI as a new creative tool comparable to animation, puppetry, or CGI that opens fresh possibilities for storytelling without replacing human actors. 2. Artistic Expression - Defenders frame Tilly as a piece of art rather than a replacement, arguing that she sparks important conversations about creativity. 3. Technical Advancement - The creator describes her as representing new possibilities in filmmaking technology, similar to how previous innovations expanded creative options.
CONS 1. Job Displacement & Threat to Human Actors - SAG-AFTRA and many actors view this as devaluing human artistry, with the union explicitly stating â€œTilly Norwood is not an actorâ€ and expressing concern about synthetic performers being used without proper contractual protections. 2. Ethical Issues with Training Data - Critics point out that hundreds of living young womenâ€™s faces were composited together to create Tilly, questioning why those real actors couldnâ€™t have been hired instead. 3. Gendered Control Concerns - Many critics noted itâ€™s â€œnot surprising the first major â€˜AI actorâ€™ is a young woman they can fully control,â€ highlighting concerns about creating a controllable female performer.
â€œDo you think Tillyâ€™s interaction on screen with human actors will be successful to the point where she and potential other AI actors will pose a genuine threat to working actors?â€
Technical Issues - Spontaneous reactions to scene partners - Physical presence and spatial awareness on set - Real-time collaboration with directors making adjustments - Genuine chemistry and emotional responsiveness - Improvisation and adaptation
The Real Concern 1. Background and minor roles - Where the performance demands are lower and cost savings are significant 2. Commercial and corporate content - Where â€œgood enoughâ€ is acceptable 3. Contractual erosion - Studios using AI to avoid paying residuals, royalties, or fair wages 4. Bargaining power - Even if AI isnâ€™t technically superior, the threat of replacement weakens actorsâ€™ negotiating positions
â€œWill this new capability, pose equal threat to newcomers in the industry and pre-established actors?â€
Emerging/Green Actors are most vulnerable becauseâ€¦

Entry-level roles that could vanish entirely
The â€œladderâ€ of incremental opportunities
Visibility and networking
Building a reel

Established/Prominent Actors are better protected because ofâ€¦ - Name recognition = box office value - Studios need stars people actually want to see - Bargaining power - Strong agents, contracts, unions protecting their likeness rights - Unique artistic value - Their specific persona, reputation, and proven audience draw - Financial cushion - Can afford to be selective and weather industry changes
But what happens to those who fall between A-List and unknown? If AI hinders newbies from entering on the ground floor, how will we create new stars to be on top?

title: Beat the Wordle
text:
The Wordle took the world by storm when it first emerged in October of 2021, incentivizing millions to compete with their friends to see who could guess the daily word in the fewest number of tries. Although Iâ€™ve never had a streak longer than 4 days, Iâ€™d like to see if I can guess the correct word in fewer tries than three LLMs.
I was able to solve the Wordle in just 4 guesses, but all three LLMs took 5 or more attempts. (example of feedback provided after each guess: â€œs-not in the word, a-correct, l-not in the word, t-wrong spot, o-not in the wordâ€)

ChatGPT: 
Claude.AI:

For each guess made by the LLMs, I clearly explained which letters were completely correct, correct but in the wrong place, or not in the word at all. Eachh LLM noted that the clear feedback enabled them to eventually solve the puzzle, showing that straightforward prompting is crucial to getting desired responses from AI models.

title: Which Animation Style is Trending
text:
Animation styles have evolved over the years as new technological capabilities have allowed them to do so. Innovation has enabled companies to transition from black-and-white to colored content, from 2D to 3D styles, and more. These new possibilities invite more diverse designs; however, there is often pushback against changed styles for franchises that remain active for extended periods. For example, the Shrek movies have been enjoyed by viewers across generations; however, the trailers for the most recent film revealed drastic changes in animation, which fueled critiques from fans of the classics. Is nostalgia stopping viewers from embracing new styles, or are certain types of animation inherently more appealing to viewers regardless of previous exposure to similar content? Letâ€™s see what AI thinks about competing ideas in animation.
AI has recognized significant changes in animation styles over the past four decades, identifying components such as line work, color vibrancy, and character expressionism as distinguishing details. While 90â€™s animations are recognized for â€œsquiggly lines and expressive character designsâ€ made famous by groups like Klasky-Csupo, this decadeâ€™s animations are praised for â€œhighly polished animation with dynamic lighting and detailed backgrounds.â€


This evolution of styles diversifies content, but how do different generations feel about new animation features?

Despite each generationâ€™s preferences, the general consensus about the shift from 90s techniques to modern animation is the followingâ€¦

Ultimately, I sought to determine if AI could generate images that mimicked the animation styles of these two decades. Can you guess which image represents each decade?

title: AI Unmasked
text:
General Thoughts
Iâ€™ve finished Joy Buolamwiniâ€™s â€œUnmasking AI,â€ and she did a great job of using the final sections to shift from diagnosis to action; hereâ€™s where she really shows her vision for what needs to change.
I really appreciated her emphasis on accountability. She discusses the need for transparency in AI systems, arguing that people have a right to know when algorithms are making decisions about their lives. She also advocates for regulatory frameworks that would hold tech companies responsible for the harms their systems cause. The point isnâ€™t to stifle innovation, but ensure that vulnerable companies arenâ€™t paying the price for it.
I was inspired by her discussion of the Algorithmic Justice League. She founded this group to fight for equitable and accountable AI, and she frames this work as part of a larger movement for civil rights in the digital age. Just as previous generations fought for equal treatment under the law, we now need to fight for equal treatment by algorithms, especially seeing how theyâ€™re increasingly governing our lives.
The book ends on a note thatâ€™s both cautionary and hopeful. She paints an optimistic picture of what inclusive AI could look like. She recognizes the scale of the challenges ahead, but also believes change is possible if we collectively demand it. Reading this book has fundamentally shifted how I think about AI. Itâ€™s not a neutral tool; it reflects our societyâ€™s values and biases, and as a collective, we have a responsibility to do better.


Questions and Reflections:

What questions remain?

Iâ€™m curious about what resistance from the tech industry would look like. How would companies respond to calls for greater accountability? Iâ€™d also like to know more about successful examples of algorithmic justice work!

What will I take away from this book moving forward?

Iâ€™ll approach AI systems with much more skepticism, especially when theyâ€™re deployed in high-stakes contexts like criminal justice or hiring.
This book is essential reading for anyone who wants to understand how AI is reshaping our world and who wants to ensure that transformation doesnâ€™t replicate the inequalities of the past.
