title: Itâ€™s Just TV
text:
I grew up watching reality shows like Dance Moms and Bring It! Both shows focus on a group of about 7 young girls who travel and dance competitively every week. While viewers get to watch the girls compete and grow in their craft, a large portion of each episode revolves around the drama between their competitive moms, all of whom desire that their child be the star of their studio. I enjoyed watching the drama when I was younger to the point where I would pick my favorite dancer and mom and pick sides during their arguments. However, rewatching these shows at an older age, I realize the potential damage done to each childâ€™s psychological health as a result of growing up in such hectic, hostile environments. The general public tends to argue that, though both shows put the girls in stressful situations due to all of the travel and new choreography that they have to juggle on top of school, the girls featured on Dance Moms had worse experiences than those on Bring It! I wanted to see if AI would be able to form an opinion on the environments of each show and conclude whether or not reality TV in general could be considered a safe environment for children.



Chat GPT was able to identify differences in the structure of each show, causing one to have produce more harmful outcomes for the young cast members. For bith shows, the competitive stress that caused the children to value perfection over performance and over-bearing schedule of being featured on reality tv were primary stressors for the children on both shows. However, AI identified the coaching styles as a distinguishing factor. The coach of dance moms placed intense pressure on the girls and promoted internal competition between teammates that viewers joined in on, leading dancers less favored to be heavily scrutinized by the public. The coach of Bring it, on the other hand, promoted community through mentorship. By not dividing the team, her leadership style enticed the viewing audience to root for the team as a whole. Bring It was decided ot be an overall healthier environment compared to Dance Moms because it fostered growth rather than stifling emotional development. When asked to generalize, AI concluded that reality tv is not a safe environment for children because of the immense pressure and lack of protection against public scrutiny.

title: Help Me With My Money
text:
The majority of Americans are unaware of how to manage their money when they enter early adulthood. Without conducting their own research, young adults are left oblivious to credit, financial management, investing, and building a sustainable net worth. Education is mandated for all US children until the completion of 12th grade, and despite offering electives in different educational areas, few schools offer students the opportunity to learn about money. Should courses on financial literacy be a required offering at all secondary and higher education schools? Should it become a mandated component of the standard curriculum? If so, at which point in a studentâ€™s education should such content be introduced, and should it replace other sub-topics that are taught universally? How can AI help us to better integrate financial literacy courses into schools?
Prompt: should financial literacy become a core part of school curriculum
Response:
Pros: - Many adults struggle with basic financial decisions (debt, interest rates, retirement savings), leading to real hardship that early education could prevent Creates equityâ€”wealthier families teach money management at home, while others lack access to this knowledge - Practical life skill with tangible, long-term benefits
Cons: - Schools already overcrowded with â€œessentialâ€ topicsâ€”something else would need to be cut or school hours extended - Research shows standalone financial literacy courses often have limited long-term impactâ€”students forget or struggle to apply lessons years later - Financial decisions are often more about behavior and circumstances than knowledge
Middle ground: - Integrate financial concepts into existing subjects (compound interest in math, economic policy in history, advertising analysis in English) - Offer as an elective rather than required course, with resources available when students need them

How would the financial health of americaâ€™s population change, if academic interventions for financial literacy were made

What studies actually show:

Most rigorous evaluations find that school-based financial literacy programs produce small improvements in financial knowledge, but these gains often fade over time The impact on actual financial behaviors (saving rates, debt levels, credit scores) is typically modest at bestâ€”many studies find no significant long-term effects A major meta-analysis found that financial education explains only about 0.1% of variance in financial behaviorsâ€”far less than factors like income, employment stability, or family background

Why interventions underperform expectations:

Timing problem: Teaching 16-year-olds about mortgages or retirement accounts doesnâ€™t stick when they wonâ€™t need that information for years or decades Knowledge-behavior gap: Understanding compound interest doesnâ€™t automatically translate to consistent saving, especially when facing immediate financial pressures Structural barriers: Financial literacy canâ€™t overcome low wages, high cost of living, medical debt, or lack of access to affordable banking services
Realistic impact if widely implemented: Americaâ€™s population would likely see marginal improvementsâ€”perhaps slightly fewer predatory loan victims, modestly better credit scores among some groups, incrementally higher emergency savings. But we wouldnâ€™t see dramatic shifts in overall financial health without addressing underlying economic factors like wage stagnation, healthcare costs, housing affordability, and wealth inequality.

Prompt:which class universally offered in schools across the united states would make the most sense to replace with financial health courses
Response:



I asked the LLM to craft 3 potential plans for integrating financial literacy into standard curriculum.
  


Which of these plans do you think would best enable financial health long-term?

title: Playing Hangman With AI

If provided with bits of information, will it be able to combine those pieces to create the whole picture? I tested both LLMs with the same 7-letter word, and though each had acquired enough letters to figure out the word, neither made a full guess, and instead guessed each letter 1-by-1, getting know more than 4 letters incorrect.

title: Iâ€™ll Just Be An Influencer
text:
Gen Zâ€™s perception of the world is largely shaped by social media. From political views to love languages, to future profession opportunities, we form opinions by engaging with other people and considering their perspectives. The authority of social media on our lives is facilitated by influencers. Especially on TikTok, people can identify an area of interest upon which to center creative content, and with the help of the TikTok algorithm, many have the potential to become popular figures with the capabilities to profit from their videos. For many, higher education has grown increasingly unattractive as a next step following high school, causing them to attempt to become influencers as their full-time career. An important part of being a successful influencer is knowing your niche. Based on supplemental information about personality and interests, Iâ€™m curious to know what type of influencer AI thinks I should be if I wanted to maximize popularity.
Hereâ€™s how the conversation went:
Me: what type of influencer content is most popular amongst TikTok viewers
Copilot:
GRWM (Get Ready With Me): Especially in beauty and fashion, these videos blend routine with personality, often using trending sounds.
Tutorials & How-Tos: Quick, digestible guidesâ€”from makeup to productivity hacksâ€”are highly engaging and shareable.
Challenges & Trends: Participating in viral challenges or remixing trending formats boosts visibility and taps into TikTokâ€™s algorithm.
POV & Storytelling: Creators use â€œPOVâ€ formats or short skits to share relatable experiences, often with humor or emotional depth.
Lifestyle Vlogs: Day-in-the-life clips, travel diaries, and personal routines help build parasocial connections.
Edutainment: Educational content with an entertaining twistâ€”especially in finance, tech, and wellnessâ€”is gaining traction.
Copilot showed the same types of content to be the most profitable for newly established influencers.
Hereâ€™s the personality/content survey I answered to determing which type of influencer I should be if I chose to follow that path!


Co-pilot advised me to try drumroll Lifestyle and Edutainment Content!
Copilot found the following types of content to be most popular and profitable for those trying to become influencers and even provided some explanation as to why they tend to resonate with audiences more than other video types. I think these types of creators benefit from the publicâ€™s craving for authenticity. We are constantly faced with big brands trying to paint themselves a certain way to incentivize purchases, so when weâ€™re faced with genuine content, weâ€™re appreciative of the vulnerability. Copoilot concluded that if I were to enter the influencer space, I would be most likely to succeed in one of the aforementioned disciplines. Though flattered by the idea of people being that invested in my day-to-day life, Iâ€™ve noticed that, recently, audiences have grown more parasocial and have even developed a sense of entitlement to being privy to the intimate details of public figuresâ€™ lives. It would be cool to be an influencer, but I need my privacy, so I think Iâ€™ll stick to a more practical career!

title: My Royal Wedding
text:
Like so many other girls, I have had my wedding designed on Pinterest since I was 10. From the neckline cut of my dress to the color scheme to the cut of my ring, I have a collection of inspiration pics that is sure to make planning easier when the time comes. Some of my tastes have certainly changed since I created my first dream board, but my primary vision remains intact. While some wedding aspects are timeless, there are a few new trends that have emerged over the past few years that I would like to incorporate, but the scariest part is, of course, the prices. Iâ€™d like to see if AI can generate ideas for my wedding, including affordable alternatives to some of my pricier ideas, and produce a wedding plan for $15,000 or less.
These are the guidelines I included in my prompt

Color scheme: teal and brown (feel free to add another color to help blend the two)
Ceremony: somewhere close to NJ, modern, florals coming from high ceiling, reflective aisle, raised altar, large windows to let light in
Reception: big open space for a dancefloor in the middle of the room surrounded by tables, moderately sized centerpieces with flowers and other accents
Food: walk-up bars from different cuisines and a dessert bar
Dress: ball gown !!or mermaid dress (Iâ€™d like to see two options)
Ring: princess cut (2.5 carats), silver band with a floral band
Extra amenities: live violinist for when walking down the aisle, live painter, â€œwalk down memory laneâ€ with pictures and brief descriptions of our relationship milestones


This design is even better than what I had imagined. The colors blend well together, and the overall visual gives the enchanting feeling that I want my wedding to have!

These reception layouts fit my suggestions and would be perfect for a small wedding. Iâ€™d definitely need more floor space for dancing, though.
Now for the most important partsâ€¦ THE GOWN AND RING


I donâ€™t really love either dress option, but Iâ€™m definitely more fond of the ball gown, so Iâ€™ll keep that in mind when itâ€™s time to go shopping. As for the ring, the design is very sleek and classic. I think I would want my band to be a little thinner but this is a great starting point!
Overall, AI was able to create visuals based on the guidelines I gave, and the results were much closer to my prompts than I expected. I will definitely be using these pictures for inspiration when the time comes!

title: Is Gen Z Lazy
text:
Post-undergraduate unemployment is at its highest level it has been in previous years. Currently standing at 4.59%, students are struggling to secure both internships and full-time positions across disciplines. While liberal arts majors are expected to have more difficulty breaking into technical roles, recently, STEM majors have also faced difficulties getting past screening stages, even if they attend target schools. Making use of social platforms like TikTok and Instagram, Gen Z has been vocal about their difficulties finding satisfying work; however, they often face backlash from older adults (GenerationX and Baby Boomers), who deem that they are lazy and do not want to work. As a member of Gen Z myself, I recognize our hustle, the hard work we put into tailoring resumes, writing cover letters, networking, and more, but perhaps that first-hand perspective makes me biased. How would AI compare Gen Zâ€™s work ethic to that of other generations? Are this generationâ€™s unemployment rates high because we are lazy, or is the market to blame?

How do LLMs compare Gen Zâ€™s work ethic in the workplace/efforts to secure jobs to that of other generations?
ğŸ‘¶ Baby Boomers (born ~1946â€“1964) - Work Ethic: Defined by loyalty, long hours, and climbing the corporate ladder. - Job Seeking: Traditionalâ€”rÃ©sumÃ©s, in-person interviews, and staying with one company for decades. - Mindset: â€œWork hard, earn stability.â€
ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’¼ Gen X (born ~1965â€“1980) - Work Ethic: Independent, pragmatic, and skeptical of authority. - Job Seeking: Balancedâ€”adapted to online applications but still value face-to-face networking. - Mindset: â€œWork smart, protect your time.â€
